E7453F00DFE60131C58B68A86D17958E.description: People encounter questions about the natural world every day.

E744F090DFE60131C58A68A86D17958E.description: Interdependence of Science, Engineering, and Technology

E745CB60DFE60131C58D68A86D17958E.description: People depend on various technologies in their lives; human life would be very different without technology.

E74586E0DFE60131C58C68A86D17958E.description: Influence of Engineering, Technology, and Science on Society and the Natural World

E7465270DFE60131C58F68A86D17958E.description: The shape and stability of structures of natural and designed objects are related to their function(s).

E744A8C0DFE60131C58968A86D17958E.description: Systems in the natural and designed world have parts that work together.

E7430890DFE60131C58468A86D17958E.description: Events have causes that generate observable patterns.

E742C4D0DFE60131C58368A86D17958E.description: Simple tests can be designed to gather evidence to support or refute student ideas about causes.

E743A350DFE60131C58668A86D17958E.description: Patterns in the natural world can be observed, used to describe phenomena, and used as evidence.

E743E970DFE60131C58768A86D17958E.description: Patterns in the natural and human designed world can be observed and used as evidence.

E741DFA0DFE60131C58068A86D17958E.description: Because there is always more than one possible solution to a problem, it is useful to compare and test designs.

E74138B0DFE60131C57E68A86D17958E.description: Designs can be conveyed through sketches, drawings, or physical models. These representations are useful in communicating ideas for a problem's solutions to other people.

E73B4FA0DFE60131C56A68A86D17958E.description: A situation that people want to change or create can be approached as a problem to be solved through engineering. Such problems may have many acceptable solutions.

E7406EE0DFE60131C57B68A86D17958E.description: Before beginning to design a solution, it is important to clearly understand the problem.

E7402A50DFE60131C57A68A86D17958E.description: A situation that people want to change or create can be approached as a problem to be solved through engineering.

E740B300DFE60131C57C68A86D17958E.description: Asking questions, making observations, and gathering information are helpful in thinking about problems.

E73FDE80DFE60131C57968A86D17958E.description: Defining and Delimiting an Engineering Problem

E73E2380DFE60131C57468A86D17958E.description: Things that people do to live comfortably can affect the world around them. But they can make choices that reduce their impacts on the land, water, air, and other living things.

E73F8B80DFE60131C57868A86D17958E.description: Some kinds of severe weather are more likely than others in a given region. Weather scientists forecast severe weather so that the communities can prepare for and respond to these events.

E73EED80DFE60131C57668A86D17958E.description: Living things need water, air, and resources from the land, and they live in places that have the things they need. Humans use natural resources for everything they do.

E73D96A0DFE60131C57268A86D17958E.description: Plants and animals can change their environment.

E73D0E50DFE60131C57068A86D17958E.description: Weather is the combination of sunlight, wind, snow or rain, and temperature in a particular region at a particular time. People measure these conditions to describe and record the weather and to notice patterns over time.

E73C70B0DFE60131C56E68A86D17958E.description: All animals need food in order to live and grow. They obtain their food from plants or from other animals. Plants need water and light to live and grow.

E73C2540DFE60131C56D68A86D17958E.description: Organization for Matter and Energy Flow in Organisms

E73AB9D0DFE60131C56868A86D17958E.description: A bigger push or pull makes things speed up or slow down more quickly.

E73B97D0DFE60131C56B68A86D17958E.description: Conservation of Energy and Energy Transfer

E739F550DFE60131C56668A86D17958E.description: When objects touch or collide, they push on one another and can change motion.

E7395940DFE60131C56468A86D17958E.description: Pushing or pulling on an object can change the speed or direction of its motion and can start or stop it.

E7390A90DFE60131C56368A86D17958E.description: Pushes and pulls can have different strengths and directions.

E7346250DFE60131C55468A86D17958E.description: Scientists look for patterns and order when making observations about the world.

E7341E20DFE60131C55368A86D17958E.description: Scientific Knowledge is Based on Empirical Evidence

E732E0A0DFE60131C54F68A86D17958E.description: Scientists use different ways to study the world.

E7329A80DFE60131C54E68A86D17958E.description: Scientific Investigations Use a Variety of Methods

E730E400DFE60131C54868A86D17958E.description: Make observations (firsthand or from media) to collect data that can be used to make comparisons.

E73127E0DFE60131C54968A86D17958E.description: With guidance, plan and conduct an investigation in collaboration with peers.

E7309E40DFE60131C54768A86D17958E.description: Planning and carrying out investigations to answer questions or test solutions to problems in K–2 builds on prior experiences and progresses to simple investigations, based on fair tests, which provide data to support explanations or design solutions.

E7380E10DFE60131C56068A86D17958E.description: Communicate solutions with others in oral and/or written forms using models and/or drawings that provide detail about scientific ideas.

E737B8A0DFE60131C55F68A86D17958E.description: Read grade-appropriate texts and/or use media to obtain scientific information to describe patterns in the natural world.

E7376A40DFE60131C55E68A86D17958E.description: Obtaining, evaluating, and communicating information in K–2 builds on prior experiences and uses observations and texts to communicate new information.

E736D990DFE60131C55C68A86D17958E.description: Use a model to represent relationships in the natural world.

E7368620DFE60131C55B68A86D17958E.description: Modeling in K–2 builds on prior experiences and progresses to include using and developing models (i.e., diagram, drawing, physical replica, diorama, dramatization, storyboard) that represent concrete events or design solutions.

E733D940DFE60131C55268A86D17958E.description: Use tools and materials provided to design and build a device that solves a specific problem or a solution to a specific problem.

E7339120DFE60131C55168A86D17958E.description: Constructing explanations and designing solutions in K–2 builds on prior experiences and progresses to the use of evidence and ideas in constructing evidence-based accounts of natural phenomena and designing solutions.

E7355DC0DFE60131C55768A86D17958E.description: Define a simple problem that can be solved through the development of a new or improved object or tool.

E735ADE0DFE60131C55868A86D17958E.description: Ask questions based on observations to find more information about the natural and/or designed world(s).

E735F9A0DFE60131C55968A86D17958E.description: Ask questions based on observations to find more information about the designed world.

E73506D0DFE60131C55668A86D17958E.description: Asking questions and defining problems in grades K–2 builds on prior experiences and progresses to simple descriptive questions that can be tested.

E7325720DFE60131C54D68A86D17958E.description: Use observations (firsthand or from media) to describe patterns in the natural world in order to answer scientific questions.

E7320EE0DFE60131C54C68A86D17958E.description: Analyze data from tests of an object or tool to determine if it works as intended.

E731C1B0DFE60131C54B68A86D17958E.description: Analyzing data in K–2 builds on prior experiences and progresses to collecting, recording, and sharing observations.

E72F8E80DFE60131C54468A86D17958E.description: Analyze data from tests of two objects designed to solve the same problem to compare the strengths and weaknesses of how each performs.

E72F4050DFE60131C54368A86D17958E.description: Develop a simple sketch, drawing, or physical model to illustrate how the shape of an object helps it function as needed to solve a given problem.

E72EFA20DFE60131C54268A86D17958E.description: Ask questions, make observations, and gather information about a situation people want to change to define a simple problem that can be solved through the development of a new or improved object or tool.

E72DD4B0DFE60131C53E68A86D17958E.description: Communicate solutions that will reduce the impact of humans on the land, water, air, and/or other living things in the local environment.
comments: Clarification Statement: Examples of human impact on the land could include cutting trees to produce paper and using resources to produce bottles. Examples of solutions could include reusing paper and recycling cans and bottles.

E72E23B0DFE60131C53F68A86D17958E.description: Ask questions to obtain information about the purpose of weather forecasting to prepare for, and respond to, severe weather.
comments: Clarification Statement: Emphasis is on local forms of severe weather.

E72D5BE0DFE60131C53D68A86D17958E.description: Use a model to represent the relationship between the needs of different plants or animals (including humans) and the places they live.
comments: Clarification Statement: Examples of relationships could include that deer eat buds and leaves, therefore, they usually live in forested areas; and, grasses need sunlight so they often grow in meadows. Plants, animals, and their surroundings make up a system.

E72C3440DFE60131C53968A86D17958E.description: Construct an argument supported by evidence for how plants and animals (including humans) can change the environment to meet their needs.
comments: Clarification Statement: Examples of plants and animals changing their environment could include a squirrel digs in the ground to hide its food and tree roots can break concrete.

E72C7BF0DFE60131C53A68A86D17958E.description: Use and share observations of local weather conditions to describe patterns over time.
comments: Clarification Statement: Examples of qualitative observations could include descriptions of the weather (such as sunny, cloudy, rainy, and warm); examples of quantitative observations could include numbers of sunny, windy, and rainy days in a month. Examples of patterns could include that it is usually cooler in the morning than in the afternoon and the number of sunny days versus cloudy days in different months.
Assessment Boundary: Assessment of quantitative observations limited to whole numbers and relative measures such as warmer/cooler.

E72B5370DFE60131C53668A86D17958E.description: Use observations to describe patterns of what plants and animals (including humans) need to survive.
comments: Clarification Statement: Examples of patterns could include that animals need to take in food but plants do not; the different kinds of food needed by different types of animals; the requirement of plants to have light; and, that all living things need water.

E72AC0F0DFE60131C53468A86D17958E.description: From Molecules to Organisms: Structures and Processes

E72A6350DFE60131C53368A86D17958E.description: Use tools and materials to design and build a structure that will reduce the warming effect of sunlight on an area.
comments: Clarification Statement: Examples of structures could include umbrellas, canopies, and tents that minimize the warming effect of the sun.

E72A12C0DFE60131C53268A86D17958E.description: Make observations to determine the effect of sunlight on Earth's surface.
comments: Clarification Statement: Examples of Earth's surface could include sand, soil, rocks, and water
Assessment Boundary: Assessment of temperature is limited to relative measures such as warmer/cooler.

E7292D90DFE60131C52F68A86D17958E.description: Analyze data to determine if a design solution works as intended to change the speed or direction of an object with a push or a pull.
comments: Clarification Statement: Examples of problems requiring a solution could include having a marble or other object move a certain distance, follow a particular path, and knock down other objects. Examples of solutions could include tools such as a ramp to increase the speed of the object and a structure that would cause an object such as a marble or ball to turn.
Assessment Boundary: Assessment does not include friction as a mechanism for change in speed.

E728E0D0DFE60131C52E68A86D17958E.description: Plan and conduct an investigation to compare the effects of different strengths or different directions of pushes and pulls on the motion of an object.
comments: Clarification Statement: Examples of pushes or pulls could include a string attached to an object being pulled, a person pushing an object, a person stopping a rolling ball, and two objects colliding and pushing on each other.

Assessment Boundary: Assessment is limited to different relative strengths or different directions, but not both at the same time. Assessment does not include non-contact pushes or pulls such as those produced by magnets.

E7283700DFE60131C52C68A86D17958E.description: Motion and Stability: Forces and Interactions
